title: "I'm not high elo but I have high elo game knowledge"
body:
Pretty edgy title, but believe it or not in a lot of ways this is going to be a big help to the mindset of lower elos. Let's not hide from the facts folks, the majority of the people on these boards are gold elo or below. And because of this on a board dedicated to the games balance, players elos often get brought up. And in response, many low elo players say "well I'm low elo but I have high elo game knowledge!" This is where things get pretty hot and I ask you read this before dismiss it angirly 

Quite simply put: no you don't. I consider the high elo threshold to be right at plat 1 and I would consider the knowledge of a diamond 1 player to be better (but it's likely the plat 1 players understands the game at a high level well enough to have a sensible discussion with much higher elo players). You might point out I'm plat 1 and this is why I feel that way. No, I was diamond season 4 and I've always felt this way - I simply haven't grinded many games yet. I just wanted to get that out of the way because I know someone would likely bring it up.

Back on topic: I'm going to tell the lower elo folks here something that might surprise you. You can have shit mechanics and still get decently high elo. Why? Because of game knowledge. Game knowledge alone can easily get you mid diamond, after that point, your mechanics do start becoming more and more important. 

When I hear a lower elo player say they have the high elo game knowledge, it's actually something concerns me. Because, in reality, if the lower elo player did, he wouldn't be low elo. You might watch streams of high elos, you might read blogs of high elos and pick up some things but that doesn't give you their game knowledge. The only way to truly get a real perspective of it is to play in it yourself. And the counter argument to this is often "well being high elo doesn't mean you have high elo game knowledge." This simply isn't true. Sure, there might be other players with their elo with much better knowledge but in reality, their knowledge is good enough to be in high elo, which will be above and beyond that of a lower elo players. In many cases, when this argument is brought up, it's because a high elo player is shit at explaining, arguing and discussing knowledge. There's no way their knowledge is shit though.

I gotta admit, this came off as extremely elitist and the truth is, it probably is. But the reason it's so concerning is if, as a low elo, you have the mindset that you have high elo game knowledge, you'll have this idea that it's only a matter of improving mechanics as you think your knowledge is sufficient when it isnt. This will lead to a lot of bad habits and the truth is, if you're not focusing on the mental aspect of the game and gaining more knowledge, you're likely not improving much. Your mechanics aren't going to improve much playing against bronze and silvers because they won't be challenged after a certain point. This is the issue most "elo hell" believers have, they're convinced they know about the game when they don't, they chirp off buzzwords they hear on streams and LCS videos and think it doesn't need to get better when in reality, it's what's holding them back. 

How is this relevant to GB? Because it makes discussing balance with the people here a pain in the ass. I will *never* dismiss any argument based on elo unless the argument is based on soley the level of play in a comparison of high elo vs low elo. But at a certain point, you have to understand that higher elo players are going to just know more about the game than you and as you want them to not be so dismissive of you because of your elo, you need to be less dismissive of them. That's not to say that high elos can't work on not being elitist ass holes because believe me, a lot of them can. But I will take their word over that of a lower elo players any day. And while that may be frustrating to hear, it's the truth. So when discussing balance, understand I will never be dismissive of you because of your elo. If your argument is well thought out, I will happily discuss it and even hopefully one of two scenarios occur: I was misinformed and learned something or I was able to teach somethig. Both are awesome.  If you're bringing up anecdotal evidence however, I will point it out because high elo > low elo.

So tl;dr, elo does matter in game knowledge and all elo players need to realize this too. And if you ever have the mindset that your game knowledge can't improve (aka you can't be wrong), you'll never get better and discussing anything balance wise with you is a waste.

I'm not going to bother to read the low elo berating in this thread. Why? I've never seen anyone say that they "have high elo game knowledge". Nor do I think that people believing that they're being held down by their teams means that they think that.

Being poor at the game doesn't somehow mean that your sense of logic is flawed. People are capable of realizing when someone is better at them at the game. They're also capable of understanding how things happen and how games should play out, even if that doesn't happen in their own games.

It's so easy for low elo players to claim that they understand, but you guys really don't. Sometimes for the very low ranked, your very foundations and basic premises of the game are so off that you can't comprehend what we're saying. This isn't to say that it's always the case, but sometimes it really is.

You claim that just because you're poor at the game doesn't mean that your sense of logic is flawed, and that low ranked people are capable of realizing when someone is better than them at the game, and also that they're capable of understanding how things happen and how games should play out even if that doesn't happen in their own games. What you're thinking of is the most basic of understandings, but what you fail to understand is the more complex ideas behind it. League isn't the static game you make it out to be, you can never simply "understand how things happen and how games should play out". It doesn't happen in your games, you have no experience with it. You may have the knowledge to overcome the initial hurdle, but then you're presented with even more branching decisions with obscure answers, and so on and so forth. You guys never run into these situations, so how in the world can you be proficient at it?

Perhaps there is a phrasing issue. Sure, you guys can understand the basic processes of the game. But can you claim to understand the complex and advanced processes of the game, and as well as a diamond player at that?

That's a logically sound argument, but the only way you're going to make this argument convincing to me is through examples. I can think of lots of things I can't do and LOTS of ways that other players are better than me.  I can't think of anything in this game that I do not understand. This game is designed so that it's easy for young teenagers to understand. What makes it a sport over a game is its consistent logic and very limited rules.

Let's say Riot implements your idea despite your completely lack of foresight as you yourself admit. The idea turns out to be completely HORRIBLE because you have not experienced its results, you don't know how it reacts in a live environment. You don't have the foresight to judge whether it's balanced or not. Following your own logic, you can draw conclusions based on established facts or observable data, however you do not have the foresight to predict unforeseen or unknown circumstances. This is an incredibly well written post. Despite its length, it doesn't ramble and it's very straight to the point with sound reasoning. I'm going to be as thorough in my response as I possibly can be and if I miss something, please point it out.

A good chunk of my post is very broad in nature. Not because I want to intentionally dis-include anything but because the nature of my belief behind this has an extreme depth to it that takes quite a bit of time and effort to explore - to be quite honest with you, I doubt most people are interested in reading that. But because you brought it up, I'll explain.

When I say game knowledge, this excludes very basic concepts of the game that any average level 30 player should have. Game knowledge isn't exactly a stat that can be measured, the higher the elo, the higher level the play is. The higher the level the play, the more complex the game becomes at a very minute level. While a lot of basics are still shared between all elos, as I've noted, it gets a bit more complex.

So when I make this statement, I make it on the backbone that there's no way a silver player can understand how to play in a diamond game. The diamond game will be much more punishing of mistakes, even the smallest positional mistakes that are often made and left unpunished in low elo. The game and the decision making are played at a much faster level. Snowballing is much harder because people know how to punish mistakes harder. While some of this is true in all elos but to a lesser and lower quality of play, as its higher, and I hate to wear this word out, it's more complex and in depth. Simply put: there's no way a lower elo player could ever understand this. The only way they do is by ranking up and experiencing it.

I'll give you an example I like using to describe this. Imagine you're watching a front page game of ranked high elo. You see a Hecarim and Darius fighting it out. Darius is running flash/ignite, Hecarim is running ignite/TP. You watch as the Darius has Hecarim under tower and below half health but Darius is barely above half himself. Darius hits six with just a few of his minions left dying under tower. Many low elo players would probably wonder why Darius isn't walking up to the escapeless Hecarim and dropping a Q/AA/R/Ignite to secure what seems like an easy kill. Instead, the Darius backs. How many people will understand why he backed instead of securing what seems like a sure kill?

Because a few things: the minion wave is going to reset in the middle of the wave after those minions die, or damn close to Hecs tower. Darius has it warded but doesn't see the jungler, he can only assume he's nearby expecting the dive. Darius would most assuredly die as well as he would draw aggro and Hecarim would likely ult him under tower. Darius has flash/ignite, not TP. So if Darius secures the kill and you'd think "snowball champion so it's a win for him," it's not. Hecarim is just going to TP back in, freeze the wave as Darius is going to be denied minions since his minions will be right under Hecs tower. They still traded 1 for 1 so Hec got a good chunk of gold and because of the freeze, Hec is going to be last hitting more and will also gain an EXP advantage to boot. Not to mention, Darius typically doesn't want to blow flash unless it's for a kill that doesn't involve his own death because of how easy he is to gank, he basically wants to have flash for straight forward sure fired kills or an escape.


In this situation, I can promise you lower elos wouldn't consider half of this and go for the dive. This is an example of small details you must always pay attention to at all times of the game. And not only must you pay attention, you must understand what's going to happen next and predict it accurately. At lower levels, this in depth knowledge and thinking just doesn't happen. And that's why I say there's no way they have the same knowledge. They may be knowledgable of the game, but understanding so many small things that a high elo player does likely just doesn't happen because they've never had to think this way and very few players, if any at all, can put a lot of this shit into words.

What impact does this have on balance knowledge?  A pretty big one. Because some champions, as a result of less knowledge and in depth thinking, can take complete advantage of this due to the natures of their kits. So as a result, from the above example, that Darius in silver would likely dive the Hecarim and die and lose ultimately in the end because that kill was actually a bad trade for him. The first thing he'd do is QQ "omg Hecarim so op I dove him killed him solo but he just farmed and outscaled me."
Hecarim might actually be op, but because of his inability to rationalize this as a mistake and blaming the champions, he actually doesn't improve. And if he were to instead focus on what he did wrong, what caused the bad trade on something that seemingly seemed good, he just got better. And over the course of time, he's going to learn more and more about the game in small intricacies because of that. So eventually, he just won't be low elo anymore. Is that to say every low elo isn't in the process of that learning experience right now? Absolutely not, but a deep understanding is still rather lacking if they're still in low elo. That's just a matter of time for them, not a matter of if.

So when I think elo, I don't actually think rank as skill. I see it as a measurement of the players ability to approve, adapt, learn and climb. Though it is skill involved, I see that skill becomes a secondary byproduct of the climb and knowledge, experience is what's likely gained first and most probably noticed by the player right away, even if subconsciously. Combine this with the above written paragraphs, and sorry, there's just no way a low elo player has the same knowledge. Not because they're stupid, not because they're incapable but because its just a matter of not experiencing the same things that higher level of play demands. 

Now, regarding mechanics. Mechanics are absolutely important. But I truly believe mechanics require a lower threshold of skill to raise in elo than knowledge does - that's not to say there's extremely gifted but less than average knowledgable mechanical Players in high el because there are. But it's a rarity. So much of this game is decide on the decisions you make from all points of the game, as long you have the bare minimum set of mechanics required to compete at your elo, you can win - it might take longer to grind up than others but you should win. As I stated, after a certain point, I don't think you can get away with poor game knowledge doing this. And as I said in my OP, I do believe there is a certain threshold in very high elo where you have to have some damn good mechanics if you want to continue to rise.  

But all this said, I will absolutely never dismiss the statements of a lower elo player just because they're lower elo. The only time I would is if they compare their games to mine and assume we see the same things - I spent quite a bit of time explaining why they don't so I believe that's clear why id mention elo at that point. And there are times, probably more common than some low elo players would like to admit, where I can read their statements and just dismiss it as low elo ranting because that shit doesn't fly in high elo. An example would be the spammed usuage of "focusing the tank." Focusing the tank is bad when your entire team blows it's load on an ulted Alistar after his combo is down or a Leona with W active while her combo is down. Focusing a ghosted Nasus, while built tanky, isn't "focusing the tank." It's focusing the biggest fucking threat to your backline and likely the enemy teams tankiesst member and largest source of damage aside from the ADC. Yes he's tanky but he's immobile and can't just walk past front lines. Applying minimal CC on him and kiting him easily kills him, and kiting him as a team more importantly since the burden is on him as an immobile melee champion to get to your back line, is not focusing the tank. Anyone who says "yeah ok focus nasus, just focus the tank. Good job on losing the fight because you focused the tank." When I see that, I just dismiss it - any high elo player would know exactly what i just explained to be true because in high elo, Nasus isn't really a problem in teamfights - he's easily dealt with. And this is just one of many examples I can name as something I'd see from low elo ranting and banter that I'm simply going to ignore and dismiss.

But again, *i will never dismiss a players statements just because of their elo alone.* if it has sound reasoning, logic, respectable knowledge behind it then I have something worth discussing. When it's just angry downvote one line spammers mad because the truth hurts, there's not much I can do. 

So if you get upset about this but you are trying to learn the game and improve your knowledge, know that the low elo banter and low elo mindset doesn't apply to you - because over a course of time you will just get better. And your knowledge will improve and expand as a result. Just know that it never ends, even at the highest of elos, knowledge and the expansion of it is ever growing. Even at the pro level this is true because the game is ever changing. So keep grinding and you'll get there. 

As for your rank, frankly it's hard to say. Unranked players can be an enigma. In some cases, they can be pretty damn good but in reality, there's no credentials backing their statements if it comes down to anecdotal evidence. But that's about it. Again, if you have solid reasoning and a presentable argument, that's something that can be discussed and elo or lack thereof should only apply to a minimal level.

I hope this covers your questions. I haven't had to think like this or lay out my thoughts like this in a long time and it's really refreshing to do so, so thank you for that. Again, if I missed something or it's unclear, ask away and I'll address it or clarify.
